comments.commentBody:
I'm probably being Petty, but I'd like to point out that I mentioned that the Manchester Guardian is now called The Guardian 27 comments before Alan Connor did.

Back to today - I'm glad to see that I was not alone in having Dion at 10D.

What with the apostles being fishermen and seeing REEL, SCROD and DAVYJONES, I had GODSNAVY early. Skorts could have been clued culottes. Portmanteau term is new to me as is ZYNGA and DENEB. NEO? Don't get this one at all. A little help?... The folks over on Sugar Hill say Yankees in four. Tiger team is certainly NOTBAD, but the Bronx club has too many ASSETS for Detroit to overcome.

The IRA Arsenal WAS destroyed in 2005.  I finally went with MXS only because I couldn't make any sense of the three crosses any other way.  Lo and behold, I got the "Success" Icon.  Can someone connect Arsenal and MXS for me?
Just go. Perfect.

EDY is a confectionary? Is this an East Coast thing? Ditto SCROD. The East Coast thing is kind of a thing for the NYTC. May have to devise a puzzle containing grunions, the 5, Bagdad by the Bay, abalone and In-and-Out. See how you like it!
Enjoyed the puzzle.  If you didn't know who was in the kitchen with Dinah, how would knowing that it was an old song lyric help?
Hooray for me!  Two beers, and I STILL managed to finish the puzzle in a decent time (for me).

As a fellow constructor, I can attest that when David Quarfoot introduces 12 never-used-before entries to an NYT puzzle at least 9 of them don't even appear in my own word list!  Now that's cutting edge work.  Bravo.
This one did seem a tad easier than most cryptics, but nevertheless delightful and amusing.

I remember Cryptic Crosswords in New York Magazine back in the 70s (perhaps they're still there, but since I don't subscribe any longer, I wouldn't know).  As I recall, the puzzles were edited by Richard Maltby and sometimes Stephen Sondheim.
Spent way too long on this one with way too little to show for time spent and without having much fun.  And I did so well yesterday!!  I think this is the appropriate EMOTICON     <: (

HiYa, Gang, Howie here! To those of you who expressed some wonderment as to my whereabouts the last several days, well I've been kinda laid low by a somewhat surprising minor heart attack, I suffered last Wednesday at 4 A.M.
I awoke with considerable tightness in my chest and immediately headed for my medicine cabinet and threw down three baby Bayer aspirins, I then sat down and waited hopefully for the pain to subside and whilst doing so i realized my mouth had become cotton-filled, It was at that point that bec the pain wasn't subsiding and now the added Marlon Brando mumbling from the Godfather, I knew soething serious might be going on, I immediately picked-up the phone and called 911 for an ambulance to come to our apartment. After describing my symtoms, the EMT'S threw my bony butt in the back of their ambulance for Blessing Hosp. here in Quincy, and shortly after arriving it was quickly determined, after they extracted some blood, that I did,indeed suffer a HA!
Later that day they shot some dye into my ticker and saw that my dear old heart was greatly deseased and come early Monday morning I will undergo a by-pass operation, as little as a triple and possibly a quadruple...Yikes!
Now you're aware as to why I haven't been able to post until about two hours ago, my Librarose, brought a laptop PC to my room that she purchased at Best Buy.
It took us over an hour to get it up and running, but I'm happy to have gotten this comment off to you guys, well, firstly, I think the world of you, and you've often expressed your warm feelings me, on Deb's WP blog, as well.
Hopefully, the Good Lord willing, come Wednesday or Thursday, of later next week, I'll be well enough to rejoin all you guys and dolls at my favorite on-line hangout?
Keep a few fingers crossed for me...:-)

WHH
How in the world did he do it?  I am flabbergasted!  Solved the puzzle, and solved 9 of the 10 celebs.  I didn't know the other person, but checked the answer at XWord Info; will have to look him up.

Fact Boy - You must be a lawyer. I agree with Martin. Haddock, cod, scrod, schmod. If it's an anonymous fish and was caught in the North Atlantic, it's a North Atlantic catch.

PS. I am not sure if Deb views calling someone a lawyer is too pejorative to post, but since I'm one, it seems like a fair comment.
The singular APPLET appears thrice in xwordinfo's database, the first time as early as 2002.

Forget it -- I remembered the MX missiles,  Interestingly they were decommissioned the same year the IRA turned over its arms caches for destruction.  Diabolical crossword construction if intentional.
Still trying to decide if I liked this one but I'm leaning toward no.  Now if all the themed answers were switched letters like Inner Ace becoming Anne Rice, that would have been something.

But Deb... swapping the E and G in greEn orGan gets you greG norEan... who's he? The only celeb who swapped within him or herself was Anne Rice (Inner Ace). I could use the X in 23A for aleX trebe? down in 68A, but there isn't a K floating around. What am I missing?
The file for today's puzzle crashes AcrossLite on my Mac every time I try to open it. Are others having the same problem?

Have to figure it this way:

Now that they have won the first game, he pitches Garcia on Sunday. If Garcia gest blown out, he empties the bullpen. Then he hopes that CC can be CC on Monday and go deep into the game. Game 4 is probably a bullpen game again and then Nova wraps things up in Game 5 and hopefully nobody has been overworked/

This might be one of those little-noted-at-the-time things that, in hindsight, loom larger. With last week's introduction of the Kindle Fire, we may have entered an age similar to the end of the 1980s, when IBM clones became the clear market leader (over Apple's desktops). To translate: people may finally "get it" that (a) data is data, and (b) iTunes sells content that has nothing to do with Apple, but (c) Amazon sells most (all?) of that content too (and more, when it comes to books), so (d) Android as your mobile platform on any OEM's device is the way to go, because (e) any electronic device, no matter how exquisite, is obsolete in a few years, so (f) you are better off buying the less expensive (but just as powerful) offerings of "the latest thing." In sum: this may herald the downfall of Apple. Seriously. But this time we won't have to go through the growing pains of the move from command-based software to icon-based versions of the same. (Remember when we were always running out of RAM and ROM, often at the same time?) Some of the smartphones running Android, for example, are already top-shelf excellent.

The Sony Reader never had a keyboard. I found it to be a far more visually appealing device (I did not have any desire for a keyboard on my ereader device) and also at the time being able to borrow books from NYPL. I have had three Sony readers,and never warmed to the kindle because of the keyboard mainly - now that in theory I might be open to this new design, it's a moot point, I love my Sony reader,and I have my iOS devices and can just use the app.
The new pricing is very attractive and I'm sure I will end up gifting more Kindles and Nooks in the future (it is great that now you can buy a kindle in a retail store,it's hard to convince elderly parent they would like something they can't see and touch !)
For the price of a copy of Adobe Photoshop, you can buy a beautiful apple computer. Photoshop is such a rip. It's bloated and slow.

Wow, another company copying Apple's creed.

"...is the place where technology and artistry converge"? Didn't Steve Jobs state something similar in his last keynote? And, didn't another company just state something similar in the past week, besides Adobe? What is with all of these companies?
Hmm, could be that the two A's have come to some sort of middle ground on the use of Flash or a replacement for same?
